trans-unit.source: Tutorial: Azure Active Directory integration with Amazon Web Service (AWS) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Tutorial: Azure Active Directory integration with Amazon Web Service (AWS) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to configure single sign-on between Azure Active Directory and Amazon Web Service (AWS).
trans-unit.target: Learn how to configure single sign-on between Azure Active Directory and Amazon Web Service (AWS).

trans-unit.source: Tutorial: Azure Active Directory integration with Amazon Web Service (AWS)
trans-unit.target: Tutorial: Azure Active Directory integration with Amazon Web Service (AWS)

trans-unit.source: The objective of this tutorial is to show you how to integrate Amazon Web Service (AWS) with Azure Active Directory (Azure AD).<html></html>Integrating Amazon Web Service (AWS) with Azure AD provides you with the following benefits:
trans-unit.target: The objective of this tutorial is to show you how to integrate Amazon Web Service (AWS) with Azure Active Directory (Azure AD).<html></html>Integrating Amazon Web Service (AWS) with Azure AD provides you with the following benefits:

trans-unit.source: You can control in Azure AD who has access to Amazon Web Service (AWS)
trans-unit.target: You can control in Azure AD who has access to Amazon Web Service (AWS)

trans-unit.source: You can enable your users to automatically get signed-on to Amazon Web Service (AWS) (Single Sign-On) with their Azure AD accounts
trans-unit.target: You can enable your users to automatically get signed-on to Amazon Web Service (AWS) (Single Sign-On) with their Azure AD accounts

trans-unit.source: You can manage your accounts in one central location - the Azure Active Directory Portal
trans-unit.target: You can manage your accounts in one central location - the Azure Active Directory Portal

trans-unit.source: If you want to know more details about SaaS app integration with Azure AD, see <link><linkText>What is application access and single sign-on with Azure Active Directory</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you want to know more details about SaaS app integration with Azure AD, see <link><linkText>What is application access and single sign-on with Azure Active Directory</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: To configure Azure AD integration with Amazon Web Service (AWS), you need the following items:
trans-unit.target: To configure Azure AD integration with Amazon Web Service (AWS), you need the following items:

trans-unit.source: An Azure AD subscription
trans-unit.target: An Azure AD subscription

trans-unit.source: An Amazon Web Service (AWS) single-sign on enabled subscription
trans-unit.target: An Amazon Web Service (AWS) single-sign on enabled subscription

trans-unit.source: To test the steps in this tutorial, we do not recommend using a production environment.
trans-unit.target: To test the steps in this tutorial, we do not recommend using a production environment.

trans-unit.source: To test the steps in this tutorial, you should follow these recommendations:
trans-unit.target: To test the steps in this tutorial, you should follow these recommendations:

trans-unit.source: You should not use your production environment, unless this is necessary.
trans-unit.target: You should not use your production environment, unless this is necessary.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an Azure AD trial environment, you can get a one-month trial <link><linkText>here</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an Azure AD trial environment, you can get a one-month trial <link><linkText>here</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Scenario Description
trans-unit.target: Scenario Description

trans-unit.source: The objective of this tutorial is to enable you to test Azure AD single sign-on in a test environment. <html></html>
trans-unit.target: The objective of this tutorial is to enable you to test Azure AD single sign-on in a test environment. <html></html>

trans-unit.source: The scenario outlined in this tutorial consists of three main building blocks:
trans-unit.target: The scenario outlined in this tutorial consists of three main building blocks:

trans-unit.source: Adding Amazon Web Service (AWS) from the gallery
trans-unit.target: Adding Amazon Web Service (AWS) from the gallery

trans-unit.source: Configuring and testing Azure AD single sign-on
trans-unit.target: Configuring and testing Azure AD single sign-on

trans-unit.source: Adding Amazon Web Service (AWS) from the gallery
trans-unit.target: Adding Amazon Web Service (AWS) from the gallery

trans-unit.source: To configure the integration of Amazon Web Service (AWS) into Azure AD, you need to add Amazon Web Service (AWS) from the gallery to your list of managed SaaS apps.
trans-unit.target: To configure the integration of Amazon Web Service (AWS) into Azure AD, you need to add Amazon Web Service (AWS) from the gallery to your list of managed SaaS apps.

trans-unit.source: To add Amazon Web Service (AWS) from the gallery, perform the following steps:
trans-unit.target: To add Amazon Web Service (AWS) from the gallery, perform the following steps:

trans-unit.source: In the Azure Management Portal, on the left navigation pane, click Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Management Portal, on the left navigation pane, click Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Active Directory</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Active Directory</linkText>

trans-unit.source: From the Directory list, select the directory for which you want to enable directory integration.
trans-unit.target: From the Directory list, select the directory for which you want to enable directory integration.

trans-unit.source: To open the applications view, in the directory view, click Applications in the top menu.
trans-unit.target: To open the applications view, in the directory view, click Applications in the top menu.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Applications</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Applications</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Add at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: Click Add at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Applications</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Applications</linkText>

trans-unit.source: On the What do you want to do dialog, click Add an application from the gallery.
trans-unit.target: On the What do you want to do dialog, click Add an application from the gallery.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Applications</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Applications</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the search box, type Amazon Web Service (AWS).
trans-unit.target: In the search box, type Amazon Web Service (AWS).

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Applications</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Applications</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the results pane, select Amazon Web Service (AWS), and then click Complete to add the application.
trans-unit.target: In the results pane, select Amazon Web Service (AWS), and then click Complete to add the application.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Applications</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Applications</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Configuring and testing Azure AD single sign-on
trans-unit.target: Configuring and testing Azure AD single sign-on

trans-unit.source: The objective of this section is to show you how to configure and test Azure AD single sign-on with Amazon Web Service (AWS) based on a test user called "Britta Simon".
trans-unit.target: The objective of this section is to show you how to configure and test Azure AD single sign-on with Amazon Web Service (AWS) based on a test user called "Britta Simon".

trans-unit.source: For single sign-on to work, Azure AD needs to know what the counterpart user in Amazon Web Service (AWS) to an user in Azure AD is. In other words, a link relationship between an Azure AD user and the related user in Amazon Web Service (AWS) needs to be established.<html></html>
trans-unit.target: For single sign-on to work, Azure AD needs to know what the counterpart user in Amazon Web Service (AWS) to an user in Azure AD is. In other words, a link relationship between an Azure AD user and the related user in Amazon Web Service (AWS) needs to be established.<html></html>

trans-unit.source: This link relationship is established by assigning the value of the user name in Azure AD as the value of the Username in Amazon Web Service (AWS).
trans-unit.target: This link relationship is established by assigning the value of the user name in Azure AD as the value of the Username in Amazon Web Service (AWS).

trans-unit.source: To configure and test Azure AD single sign-on with Amazon Web Service (AWS), you need to complete the following building blocks:
trans-unit.target: To configure and test Azure AD single sign-on with Amazon Web Service (AWS), you need to complete the following building blocks:

trans-unit.source: **<link><linkText>Configuring Azure AD Single Single Sign-On</linkText><title></title></link>** - to enable your users to use this feature.
trans-unit.target: **<link><linkText>Configuring Azure AD Single Single Sign-On</linkText><title></title></link>** - to enable your users to use this feature.

trans-unit.source: **<link><linkText>Creating an Azure AD test user</linkText><title></title></link>** - to test Azure AD single sign-on with Britta Simon.
trans-unit.target: **<link><linkText>Creating an Azure AD test user</linkText><title></title></link>** - to test Azure AD single sign-on with Britta Simon.

trans-unit.source: **<link><linkText>Creating a Amazon Web Service (AWS) test user</linkText><title></title></link>** - to have a counterpart of Britta Simon in Amazon Web Service (AWS) that is linked to the Azure AD representation of her.
trans-unit.target: **<link><linkText>Creating a Amazon Web Service (AWS) test user</linkText><title></title></link>** - to have a counterpart of Britta Simon in Amazon Web Service (AWS) that is linked to the Azure AD representation of her.

trans-unit.source: **<link><linkText>Assigning the Azure AD test user</linkText><title></title></link>** - to enable Britta Simon to use Azure AD single sign-on.
trans-unit.target: **<link><linkText>Assigning the Azure AD test user</linkText><title></title></link>** - to enable Britta Simon to use Azure AD single sign-on.

trans-unit.source: **<link><linkText>Testing Single Sign-On</linkText><title></title></link>** - to verify whether the configuration works.
trans-unit.target: **<link><linkText>Testing Single Sign-On</linkText><title></title></link>** - to verify whether the configuration works.

trans-unit.source: Configuring Azure AD Single Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target: Configuring Azure AD Single Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source: The objective of this section is to enable Azure AD single sign-on in the Azure AD portal and to configure single sign-on in your Amazon Web Service (AWS) application.<html></html>
trans-unit.target: The objective of this section is to enable Azure AD single sign-on in the Azure AD portal and to configure single sign-on in your Amazon Web Service (AWS) application.<html></html>

trans-unit.source: Your Amazon Web Service (AWS) application expects the SAML assertions in a specific format, which requires you to add custom attribute mappings to your saml token attributes configuration.
trans-unit.target: Your Amazon Web Service (AWS) application expects the SAML assertions in a specific format, which requires you to add custom attribute mappings to your saml token attributes configuration.

trans-unit.source: The following screenshot shows an example for this.
trans-unit.target: The following screenshot shows an example for this.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html> <linkText>Configure Single Sign-On</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html> <linkText>Configure Single Sign-On</linkText>

trans-unit.source: To configure Azure AD single sign-on with Amazon Web Service (AWS), perform the following steps:
trans-unit.target: To configure Azure AD single sign-on with Amazon Web Service (AWS), perform the following steps:

trans-unit.source: In the Azure AD portal, on the Amazon Web Service (AWS) application integration page, click Configure single sign-on to open the Configure Single Sign-On dialog.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure AD portal, on the Amazon Web Service (AWS) application integration page, click Configure single sign-on to open the Configure Single Sign-On dialog.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Configure Single Sign-On</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Configure Single Sign-On</linkText>

trans-unit.source: On the How would you like users to sign on to Amazon Web Service (AWS) page, select Azure AD Single Sign-On, and then click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the How would you like users to sign on to Amazon Web Service (AWS) page, select Azure AD Single Sign-On, and then click Next.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Configure Single Sign-On</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Configure Single Sign-On</linkText>

trans-unit.source: On the Configure App Settings dialog page, click Next. Configure App Settings
trans-unit.target: On the Configure App Settings dialog page, click Next. Configure App Settings

trans-unit.source: On the Configure single sign-on at Amazon Web Service (AWS) page, click Download metadata, and then save the metadata file locally on your computer.Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target: On the Configure single sign-on at Amazon Web Service (AWS) page, click Download metadata, and then save the metadata file locally on your computer.Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source: In a different browser window, sign-on to your Amazon Web Service (AWS) company site as administrator.
trans-unit.target: In a different browser window, sign-on to your Amazon Web Service (AWS) company site as administrator.

trans-unit.source: Click Console Home. Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target: Click Console Home. Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source: Click Identity and Access Management. Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target: Click Identity and Access Management. Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source: Click Identity Providers, and then click Create Provider. Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target: Click Identity Providers, and then click Create Provider. Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source: On the Configure Provider dialog page, perform the following steps: Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target: On the Configure Provider dialog page, perform the following steps: Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source: As Provider Type, select SAML.
trans-unit.target: As Provider Type, select SAML.

trans-unit.source: In the Provider Name textbox, type a provider name (e.g.: WAAD).
trans-unit.target: In the Provider Name textbox, type a provider name (e.g.: WAAD).

trans-unit.source: To upload your downloaded metadata file, click Choose File.
trans-unit.target: To upload your downloaded metadata file, click Choose File.

trans-unit.source: Click Next Step.
trans-unit.target: Click Next Step.

trans-unit.source: On the Verify Provider Information dialog page, click Create. Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target: On the Verify Provider Information dialog page, click Create. Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source: Go to Roles > Create New Role. Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target: Go to Roles > Create New Role. Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source: On the Set Role Name dialog, perform the following steps: Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target: On the Set Role Name dialog, perform the following steps: Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source: In the Role Name textbox, type a role name (e.g.: TestUser).
trans-unit.target: In the Role Name textbox, type a role name (e.g.: TestUser).

trans-unit.source: Click Next Step.
trans-unit.target: Click Next Step.

trans-unit.source: On the Select Role Type dialog, perform the following steps: Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target: On the Select Role Type dialog, perform the following steps: Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source: Select Role For Identity Provider Access.
trans-unit.target: Select Role For Identity Provider Access.

trans-unit.source: In the Grant Web Single Sign-On (WebSSO) access to SAML providers section, click Select.
trans-unit.target: In the Grant Web Single Sign-On (WebSSO) access to SAML providers section, click Select.

trans-unit.source: On the Establish Trust dialog, perform the following steps: <html></html><html></html> <linkText>Configure Single Sign-On</linkText>
trans-unit.target: On the Establish Trust dialog, perform the following steps: <html></html><html></html> <linkText>Configure Single Sign-On</linkText>

trans-unit.source: As SAML provider, select the SAML provider you have created previousley (e.g.: WAAD)
trans-unit.target: As SAML provider, select the SAML provider you have created previousley (e.g.: WAAD)

trans-unit.source: On the Azure AD portal, select the single sign-on configuration confirmation, and then click Next.What is Azure AD Connect
trans-unit.target: On the Azure AD portal, select the single sign-on configuration confirmation, and then click Next.What is Azure AD Connect

trans-unit.source: On the Single sign-on confirmation page, click Complete to close the Configure single sign-on dialog.What is Azure AD Connect
trans-unit.target: On the Single sign-on confirmation page, click Complete to close the Configure single sign-on dialog.What is Azure AD Connect

trans-unit.source: In the menu on the top, click Attributes to open the SAML Token Attributes dialog. Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target: In the menu on the top, click Attributes to open the SAML Token Attributes dialog. Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source: Click add user attribute. Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target: Click add user attribute. Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source: On the Add User Attribute dialog, perform the following steps. <html></html><html></html> <linkText>Configure Single Sign-On</linkText>
trans-unit.target: On the Add User Attribute dialog, perform the following steps. <html></html><html></html> <linkText>Configure Single Sign-On</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Attribute Name textbox, type https://aws.amazon.com/SAML/Attributes/Role.
trans-unit.target: In the Attribute Name textbox, type https://aws.amazon.com/SAML/Attributes/Role.

trans-unit.source: In the Attribute Value textbox, type arn:aws:iam::214510765665:role/Admin,arn:aws:iam::214510765665:saml-provider/WAAD.
trans-unit.target: In the Attribute Value textbox, type arn:aws:iam::214510765665:role/Admin,arn:aws:iam::214510765665:saml-provider/WAAD.

trans-unit.source: Click Complete to close the Add User Attribute dialog.
trans-unit.target: Click Complete to close the Add User Attribute dialog.

trans-unit.source: Click add user attribute. Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target: Click add user attribute. Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source: On the Add User Attribute dialog, perform the following steps. <html></html><html></html> <linkText>Configure Single Sign-On</linkText>
trans-unit.target: On the Add User Attribute dialog, perform the following steps. <html></html><html></html> <linkText>Configure Single Sign-On</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Attribute Name textbox, type https://aws.amazon.com/SAML/Attributes/RoleSessionName.
trans-unit.target: In the Attribute Name textbox, type https://aws.amazon.com/SAML/Attributes/RoleSessionName.

trans-unit.source: In the Attribute Value list, select user:mail.
trans-unit.target: In the Attribute Value list, select user:mail.

trans-unit.source: Click Complete to close the Add User Attribute dialog.
trans-unit.target: Click Complete to close the Add User Attribute dialog.

trans-unit.source: Click Apply Changes. Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target: Click Apply Changes. Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source: Creating an Azure AD test user
trans-unit.target: Creating an Azure AD test user

trans-unit.source: The objective of this section is to create a test user in the Azure portal called Britta Simon.<html></html>
trans-unit.target: The objective of this section is to create a test user in the Azure portal called Britta Simon.<html></html>

trans-unit.source: In the Users list, select Britta Simon.Creating an Azure AD test user
trans-unit.target: In the Users list, select Britta Simon.Creating an Azure AD test user

trans-unit.source: To create a test user in Azure AD, perform the following steps:
trans-unit.target: To create a test user in Azure AD, perform the following steps:

trans-unit.source: In the Azure Management Portal, on the left navigation pane, click Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Management Portal, on the left navigation pane, click Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Creating an Azure AD test user</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Creating an Azure AD test user</linkText>

trans-unit.source: From the Directory list, select the directory for which you want to enable directory integration.
trans-unit.target: From the Directory list, select the directory for which you want to enable directory integration.

trans-unit.source: To display the list of users, in the menu on the top, click Users.Creating an Azure AD test user
trans-unit.target: To display the list of users, in the menu on the top, click Users.Creating an Azure AD test user

trans-unit.source: To open the Add User dialog, in the toolbar on the bottom, click Add User. Creating an Azure AD test user
trans-unit.target: To open the Add User dialog, in the toolbar on the bottom, click Add User. Creating an Azure AD test user

trans-unit.source: On the Tell us about this user dialog page, perform the following steps: Creating an Azure AD test user
trans-unit.target: On the Tell us about this user dialog page, perform the following steps: Creating an Azure AD test user

trans-unit.source: As Type Of User, select New user in your organization.
trans-unit.target: As Type Of User, select New user in your organization.

trans-unit.source: In the User Name textbox, type BrittaSimon.
trans-unit.target: In the User Name textbox, type BrittaSimon.

trans-unit.source: Click Next.
trans-unit.target: Click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the User Profile dialog page, perform the following steps: Creating an Azure AD test user
trans-unit.target: On the User Profile dialog page, perform the following steps: Creating an Azure AD test user

trans-unit.source: In the First Name textbox, type Britta.
trans-unit.target: In the First Name textbox, type Britta.

trans-unit.source: In the Last Name txtbox, type, Simon.
trans-unit.target: In the Last Name txtbox, type, Simon.

trans-unit.source: In the Display Name textbox, type Britta Simon.
trans-unit.target: In the Display Name textbox, type Britta Simon.

trans-unit.source: In the Role list, select User.
trans-unit.target: In the Role list, select User.

trans-unit.source: Click Next.
trans-unit.target: Click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Get temporary password dialog page, click create.Creating an Azure AD test user
trans-unit.target: On the Get temporary password dialog page, click create.Creating an Azure AD test user

trans-unit.source: On the Get temporary password dialog page, perform the following steps:Creating an Azure AD test user
trans-unit.target: On the Get temporary password dialog page, perform the following steps:Creating an Azure AD test user

trans-unit.source: Write down the value of the New Password.
trans-unit.target: Write down the value of the New Password.

trans-unit.source: Click Complete.
trans-unit.target: Click Complete.

trans-unit.source: Creating a Amazon Web Service (AWS) test user
trans-unit.target: Creating a Amazon Web Service (AWS) test user

trans-unit.source: The objective of this section is to create a user called Britta Simon in Amazon Web Service (AWS).
trans-unit.target: The objective of this section is to create a user called Britta Simon in Amazon Web Service (AWS).

trans-unit.source: To create a user called Britta Simon in Amazon Web Service (AWS), perform the following steps:
trans-unit.target: To create a user called Britta Simon in Amazon Web Service (AWS), perform the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Log in to your Amazon Web Service (AWS) company site as administrator.
trans-unit.target: Log in to your Amazon Web Service (AWS) company site as administrator.

trans-unit.source: Click the Console Home icon. Configure Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target: Click the Console Home icon. Configure Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source: Click Identity and Access Management. <html></html><html></html> <linkText>Configure Single Sign-On</linkText>
trans-unit.target: Click Identity and Access Management. <html></html><html></html> <linkText>Configure Single Sign-On</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Dashboard, click Users, and then click Create New Users. <html></html><html></html> <linkText>Configure Single Sign-On</linkText>
trans-unit.target: In the Dashboard, click Users, and then click Create New Users. <html></html><html></html> <linkText>Configure Single Sign-On</linkText>

trans-unit.source: On the Create User dialog, perform the following steps: <html></html><html></html> <linkText>Configure Single Sign-On</linkText>
trans-unit.target: On the Create User dialog, perform the following steps: <html></html><html></html> <linkText>Configure Single Sign-On</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Enter User Names textboxes, type Brita Simon's user name in Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: In the Enter User Names textboxes, type Brita Simon's user name in Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: Click Create.
trans-unit.target: Click Create.

trans-unit.source: Assigning the Azure AD test user
trans-unit.target: Assigning the Azure AD test user

trans-unit.source: The objective of this section is to enabling Britta Simon to use Azure single sign-on by granting her access to Amazon Web Service (AWS).
trans-unit.target: The objective of this section is to enabling Britta Simon to use Azure single sign-on by granting her access to Amazon Web Service (AWS).

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html><linkText>Assign User</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html><linkText>Assign User</linkText>

trans-unit.source: To assign Britta Simon to CloudPassage, perform the following steps:
trans-unit.target: To assign Britta Simon to CloudPassage, perform the following steps:

trans-unit.source: On the Azure portal, to open the applications view, in the directory view, click Applications in the top menu.
trans-unit.target: On the Azure portal, to open the applications view, in the directory view, click Applications in the top menu.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html><linkText>Assign User</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html><linkText>Assign User</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the applications list, select Amazon Web Service (AWS).
trans-unit.target: In the applications list, select Amazon Web Service (AWS).

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html><linkText>Assign User</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html><linkText>Assign User</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the menu on the top, click Users.
trans-unit.target: In the menu on the top, click Users.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html><linkText>Assign User</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html><linkText>Assign User</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Users list, select Britta Simon.
trans-unit.target: In the Users list, select Britta Simon.

trans-unit.source: In the toolbar on the bottom, click Assign.
trans-unit.target: In the toolbar on the bottom, click Assign.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html><linkText>Assign User</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Testing Single Sign-On
trans-unit.target: Testing Single Sign-On

trans-unit.source: The objective of this section is to test your Azure AD single sign-on configuration using the Access Panel.<html></html>
trans-unit.target: The objective of this section is to test your Azure AD single sign-on configuration using the Access Panel.<html></html>

trans-unit.source: When you click the Amazon Web Service (AWS) tile in the Access Panel, you should get automatically signed-on to your Amazon Web Service (AWS) application.
trans-unit.target: When you click the Amazon Web Service (AWS) tile in the Access Panel, you should get automatically signed-on to your Amazon Web Service (AWS) application.
